posts.name: Ben Bistline
posts.cooked:
Hi all,

My team first used swerve in IR@H, and we were very pleased with the results, but moving into off-season, we have some concerns. One of the concerns we have is the threat the barriers at the rendezvous point pose. Although we can travel over them, we cannot move quickly. I’ve seen a lot of cool devices to help protect modules, but I’m wondering if anyone has any quick solutions that could be implemented in less than a month.

Thanks!

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Drive it like you stole it

posts.custom_user_title: Drive it like you stole it

posts.name: Tinnittin
posts.cooked: Team 16: Bomb Squad uses some skids as can be seen here: https://youtu.be/ploXa5du4kc?t=31 I’m not sure if these are 3D printed but they look pretty easy to design and make. However, they only allow you to hit the barrier in two directions.

@AllenGregoryIV had some posted publicly iirc

Several others have posted designs as well. As far as I can tell a conical skid is ideal. Warm up your 3d printer and give it a whirl.

posts.name: Nick Coussens
posts.cooked:
If the skid is being mounted to the fixed part of the chassis, then conical will be best as it will allow an approach over the bump at any angle.

If you are going to mount skids to the actual forks of the module, then it does not need to be conical as the skids will follow the direction of travel of the wheel.

I believe 148’s solution was similar to the latter, someone else who has seen it in person or has pics or direct knowledge can confirm this or correct me if I am wrong.

posts.name: Mark Wasserman
posts.cooked:
If you can figure out the conical skid, IMO thats the best. If you can incorporate the skid into the swerve saddle (148s swerve)

Print the skids as shown. Use the magical blue plastic (HDPE??)

posts.custom_user_title: Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly

posts.name: Yair Kornblau
posts.cooked:
We have hollow conical skids on our robot and they work well. We milled the prototype on our router out of ABS, with the final version milled out of Delrin on a sponsor’s 4 axis mill. Even after a lot of abuse they managed to protect everything, but I still don’t recommend driving over the barriers at full speed, the other components of the robot generally don’t like the impacts.

The picture is of the first iteration on our prototype bot
